author: By Emma G. Fitzsimmons and Dana Rubinstein
title: Mayor Adams Loses Showdown Over 2 Criminal Justice Bills
description: The New York City Council overrode the mayor’s veto of two bills that would expand documentation of police stops and end solitary confinement.
content: Police officers will be required to record the race, age and gender of most people they stop and solitary confinement will be banned in New York City jails after the City Council overrode Mayor Eric Adams’s veto of two criminal justice bills on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: The Curmudgeon of Rivington Street
description: As his apartment on the Lower East Side crumbled, a former Club Kid resented the moneyed millennials who filled his building. Then he let them in on a secret that transformed their lives.
content: The drag queens who once paraded through the hallways are long gone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David J. Bier
title: What Biden Can Do After Another Failed Border Deal
description: Without the chaos to exploit, the Republican advantage on this issue will fall.
content: A bipartisan immigration deal to restrict border crossings took a hit last week when Donald Trump pushed Congress to reject it. It’s the latest in a series of episodes over the last decade where one party blows up a deal just as the other gives in. President Biden wants to break this cycle, but to get the politics right, he must get the policy right first.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alice Callahan
title: How Does Alcohol Affect the Gut Microbiome?
description: Scientists are just beginning to explore the relationship between drinking and the good and bad bacteria in your gut.
content: A frothy beer or a glass of wine can enhance a meal and settle the mind. But what does alcohol do to the trillions of microbes living in your gut?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: Man Who Shot Bride and Bishop at Wedding Gets 50 Years to Life in Prison
description: Dale Holloway, 41, was sentenced Monday on several charges, including attempted murder, for opening fire at a New Hampshire church in 2019 in what the authorities called a revenge shooting.
content: A gunman who opened fire in a New Hampshire church during a wedding, wounding the bride and bishop, was sentenced Monday to a minimum of 50 years to life in prison.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater and Catie Edmondson
title: Justice Department Investigating Cori Bush’s Handling of Campaign Funds
description: Investigators have raised questions about the Missouri Democrat’s hiring of her husband to provide her with security. A congressional ethics inquiry dismissed charges that the arrangement was inappropriate.
content: The Justice Department is conducting an investigation into whether Representative Cori Bush mishandled campaign funds, including when she hired her romantic partner — who is now her husband — to provide her with security services.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Tiny Love Stories: ‘He’s a Minimalist; I’m a Hoarder’
description: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
content: For our 12th anniversary, I gave my boyfriend an empty box, his most-wanted anti-gift. He’s a minimalist; I’m a hoarder. That difference has been the source of our most epic and ongoing arguments. Whenever I ask what I should buy him, he tells me to clear out my belongings from his closet. This January, I finally did. Rather than painstakingly analyzing each photo, tangled piece of jewelry or DVD in my box marked “mementos,” I set a timer for 30 minutes and discarded ruthlessly. It was difficult, but his grin was worth it. — Rachel Kramer Bussel
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Taylor Swift and the N.F.L.
description: Are TV broadcasts focusing on the pop star too much?
content: Please note: We ask that adults respect the intent of our writing prompts and refrain from posting here. While there are many other places on nytimes.com for adults to have their say, this is the only part of the site that explicitly invites the voices of young people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein and Shane Goldmacher
title: Biden Super PAC Plans a Historic $250 Million Ad Blitz
description: The flood of TV and digital spots in battleground states is set to be the largest single purchase of political advertising by a super PAC in U.S. history, according to the group, Future Forward.
content: The main Democratic super PAC supporting President Biden’s re-election bid, Future Forward, is beginning this week to reserve $250 million in advertising across the most important battleground states, a blitz that it says is the largest single purchase of political advertising by a super PAC in the nation’s history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pete Wells
title: The Patty Melt Is Tired of Hearing About Your Favorite Burger
description: The undersung cousin of an American classic is a superior sandwich, our critic argues.
content: We patty-melt people will always be outnumbered by the hamburger people, and we know it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Weinstein
title: Breakfast for Dinner!
description: Green shakshuka, sweet potato hash, miso-butter mushrooms with silky eggs: Welcome to Five Weeknight Breakfasts.
content: Egg lovers, rejoice: This week we’re talking breakfast for dinner, a beloved genre of cooking and a subject that several of you requested when I asked if you were interested last week. (Sample reader email in my inbox: “Brunch, brinner!! All breakfast edition YES!”)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Ewing
title: Truck Makers Team Up to Push for Electric Vehicle Chargers
description: Daimler, Navistar and Volvo have been criticized for not selling many electric heavy trucks, but the companies say the country first needs many more chargers.
content: There are more than four million electric vehicles on American roads, but fewer than 1,000 of them are heavy-duty trucks. On Tuesday, the three largest truck makers announced a push to remedy that deficit by calling on governments and utilities to help them build many more places to charge big rigs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Schmitt
title: Biden Says U.S. Response to Deadly Drone Strike in Jordan Has Been Decided
description: The president vowed to retaliate after the attack, which killed three American soldiers on Sunday. On Tuesday, he confirmed a decision without providing details.
content: President Biden said on Tuesday that he had decided on a U.S. response to the drone attack on a remote outpost in Jordan on Sunday that killed three American soldiers and injured more than 40 others, leaving unstated what that decision was.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liz Alderman
title: Eurozone Economy Flatlines, Raising Concerns About Falling Behind
description: The anemic pace of growth in Europe, dragged down by a weak German economy, is widening the gap with the United States.
content: The eurozone economy stagnated late last year as a lingering energy crisis sparked a loss of competitiveness in some European industries, and consumers reined in spending to grapple with high living costs, Europe’s statistics agency reported Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Goldbaum
title: Imran Khan Sentenced to 10 Years Ahead of Pakistan’s Elections
description: The verdict is widely seen as part of a military-led campaign to sideline Mr. Khan’s political party.
content: Former Prime Minister Imran Khan of Pakistan was sentenced to 10 years in prison on Tuesday, the latest twist in what is widely seen as a campaign by the military to sideline one of its leading critics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ezra Marcus
title: How Do You Make a Weed Empire? Sell It Like Streetwear.
description: Berner, the San Francisco rapper, has built a legal-weed empire out of his black-market past — and blurred the lines between the two.
content: The closest thing to a bat signal for stoners is the blue lettering of the Cookies logo. When a new storefront comes to a strip mall or a downtown shopping district, fans flock to grand-opening parties, drawn by a love of the brand — one based on more than its reputation for selling extremely potent weed. Until recently, the company was largely a West Coast phenomenon, but as marijuana legalization spread east, so did Cookies. A little over a year after recreational sales became legal in New Jersey, the chain opened a new location in a bland outdoor mall in Harrison, its aesthetic landing somewhere in the startup-meets-streetwear zone between Apple and Kith. I walked over to a large circular table laden with dozens of jars, each containing a different strain. There were longtime Cookies stalwarts like Gary Payton, a collaboration with the N.B.A. legend, and new variants with names like Mexican Flan and Dirty Muffler.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: Britain’s Foreign Secretary Signals Willingness to Recognize Palestinian State Sooner
description: David Cameron, the foreign secretary, said that his country and other allies should show Palestinians “irreversible progress” toward an independent state.
content: David Cameron, Britain’s foreign secretary, has signaled that Britain is willing to move up conversations about formally recognizing a Palestinian state, saying that his country and other allies should show Palestinians “irreversible progress” toward that long-sought goal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Chita Rivera: A Life in Photos
description: A performer who never retired is remembered for her electric Broadway performances and daring cabaret work.
content: The dancer Chita Rivera, who “dazzled audiences for nearly seven decades as a Puerto Rican lodestar of the American musical theater,” has died at 91. Her influence can be seen in many Broadway productions over the years, including “West Side Story” (1957), “Bye Bye Birdie” (1960), “Chicago” (1975) and “Kiss of the Spider Woman” (1993).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja and Andrew Das
title: Russian Skaters Stripped of Olympic Gold, Setting Up New Legal Fight
description: A decision to address the disqualification of Kamila Valieva gave the United States the gold in the Beijing 2022 team event, but it kept Canada off the podium.
content: International skating’s governing body on Tuesday sought to put an end to a two-year-old controversy by revising the disputed results of a marquee figure skating competition at the 2022 Beijing Winter Olympics. But in stripping Russia of its victory in the team event, awarding the gold medal to the United States and denying Canada the bronze it had been expecting, the sport may have only set the stage for yet another protracted legal fight.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abbie Kozolchyk
title: Linda Ronstadt’s Tucson
description: The Rock & Roll Hall of Famer known for hits like “Blue Bayou” and “Long Long Time” recommends spots she adores in the city where she was born and raised.
content: In the course of becoming a Rock & Roll Hall of Famer, a Grammy Lifetime Achievement Award winner and the subject of a forthcoming biopic set to star Selena Gomez, Linda Ronstadt has packed theaters around the globe. But her favorite sits on a one-way side street in Tucson, Ariz.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zain Khalid
title: A Return to the Fatherland in Search of a Missing Father
description: In Leo Vardiashvili’s first novel, “Hard by a Great Forest,” a young man begins a fraught quest in the country he once fled.
content: “Hard by a Great Forest,” by Leo Vardiashvili, is a novel-as-postcard from a dissolute Georgia. Our narrator, the self-abnegating and guilt-ridden Saba, fled the former Soviet republic with his father and brother amid civil war, and arrived in 1990s London at the age of 8. Nearly two decades later, his father, Irakli, flies alone to Tbilisi to reconcile his past and goes missing. “I left a trail I can’t erase,” reads Irakli’s final message to his sons. “Do not follow it.” Naturally, Saba follows.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth A. Harris
title: The Most Powerful Person in Publishing Doesn’t Like to Talk About Himself
description: Nihar Malaviya, Penguin Random House’s C.E.O., is a behind-the-scenes operator with a significant task: leading the company after a period of messy, and expensive, turbulence.
content: As chief executive of Penguin Random House, Nihar Malaviya runs a global company and the largest book publisher in the United States — a powerful cultural force that helps drive public debate and shape the country’s entertainment and literary worlds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daisuke Wakabayashi and Claire Fu
title: China’s Real Estate Crisis ‘Has Not Touched Bottom’
description: The forced liquidation of China Evergrande epitomizes the sector’s struggles: Nationwide, sales are down and millions of homes have been paid for but not delivered.
content: The unwavering belief of Chinese home buyers that real estate was a can’t-lose investment propelled the country’s property sector to become the backbone of its economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karoun Demirjian
title: House Republicans Press Ahead on Impeaching Mayorkas Over Border Policies
description: Republicans began pushing through articles of impeachment charging the homeland security secretary with refusing to uphold the law and breaching the public’s trust.
content: Republicans on the House Homeland Security Committee pressed ahead Tuesday on impeaching Alejandro N. Mayorkas, the homeland security secretary, for his handling of the southwestern border, racing forward with a partisan indictment of President Biden’s immigration policies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Beatrice Loayza
title: A Mind-Bending 7-Hour Epic About Hitler Gets a Rare Screening
description: Hans-Jürgen Syberberg’s surreal film collage was a cause celebre when it reached the United States in 1980. It’s a fascinating contrast with current Holocaust dramas.
content: This weekend, the hottest ticket in New York is a seven-hour-plus movie about Adolf Hitler.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria Kim
title: Aid Group Calls Halts in Funding for UNRWA ‘Reckless’
description: The U.S. and some other donor countries said they would suspend funding for the agency after Israel charged that a dozen of its workers had played a role in the Oct. 7 attack or its aftermath.
content: Aid groups working in Gaza expressed dismay at the decision by some donor nations to suspend funding to the main U.N. agency operating in the territory, calling the move “reckless” at a moment when the humanitarian crisis there is rapidly getting worse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Tuesday Briefing
description: Biden weighs a response to Iran.
content: President Biden is faced with a decision on how far he is willing to go after a drone strike killed three U.S. soldiers at a base in Jordan on Sunday. He vowed to respond to the attack, which he blamed on militant groups backed by Iran, but retaliation could risk a wider war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Ewing and Peter Eavis
title: Elon Musk’s Tesla Pay Package Is Voided by Judge
description: Shareholders had sued, arguing that Mr. Musk’s compensation — which helped make him the world’s richest person — was excessive.
content: Elon Musk, the chief executive of Tesla, suffered a stunning rebuke Tuesday when a Delaware judge voided the pay package that helped make him a billionaire many times over and the world’s wealthiest human being.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Sperling
title: Using A.I., Hollywood Agency and Tech Start-Up Aim to Protect Artists
description: WME said the partnership would help its clients get fake images of themselves removed or receive compensation for use of their likenesses.
content: The talent agency WME announced a partnership with the technology firm Vermillio on Tuesday that it hopes will protect its clients from having their likenesses misused through artificial intelligence technology.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenna Russell and Matt Cosby
title: On Nantucket, a Legal Maneuver to Protect Historic Homes From Gutting
description: A steady erosion of history has been underway on the island for years, with ultrawealthy newcomers remaking the interiors of antique structures.
content: On an island where the average home sale topped $4 million last year, Ginger Andrews’s scallop shanty is a golden ticket.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Woolfe
title: At 80, the Modest Queen of Contemporary Music Keeps Exploring
description: The pianist Ursula Oppens will celebrate her birthday at Merkin Concert Hall with a program drawn from the large catalog of works written for her.
content: On a cold afternoon in early January, the pianist Ursula Oppens was making an album at Brooklyn College.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Weise
title: Microsoft Reports 33% Rise in Profit
description: Revenue was up 18% in the latest quarter, the tech giant said, as investors look for signs that it’s beginning to profit from artificial intelligence.
content: Two weeks ago, Microsoft topped Apple as the most valuable public company. Last week, it surpassed $3 trillion in market valuation. Next week, Satya Nadella will hit his 10th anniversary as the company’s chief executive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rob Copeland
title: Citi Is Sued by New York State Over Account Transfer Fraud
description: New York’s attorney general said the bank failed to protect its customers from hackers who, in some cases, stole their life savings and college funds.
content: New York State’s attorney general sued Citi on Tuesday, accusing it of failing to stop scammers from stealing an unspecified amount of money from customer accounts, and saying the bank should reimburse fraud victims for any losses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Green
title: Chita Rivera, Finding Her Voice
description: Her dancing sometimes overshadowed her thrillingly dramatic way with a song: husky yet clarion, unaffected but full of comment and character.
content: Yes, the legs. Yes, the line. Yes, the look.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Dailey and Anna Betts
title: States Where the Death Penalty Has Stalled Look to Alabama
description: A bill in Ohio, which hasn’t executed anyone since 2018, would allow the state to adopt a method first used in Alabama last week.
content: Days after Alabama became the first state to put an inmate to death using nitrogen gas, officials elsewhere have started considering the new method of execution.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Washed Out
description: Freddie Cheng assembles a body of experts.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Kolata
title: Experimental Drug Cuts Off Pain at the Source, Company Says
description: Vertex Pharmaceuticals said its medicine could address moderate to severe acute pain, and might be able to avoid the risk of addiction.
content: Vertex Pharmaceuticals of Boston announced Tuesday that it had developed an experimental drug that relieves moderate to severe pain, blocking pain signals before they can get to the brain. It works only on peripheral nerves — those outside the brain and the spinal cord — making it unlike opioids. Vertex says its new drug is expected to avoid opioids’ potential to lead to addiction.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Celia McGee
title: The Secret of Thomas Mann’s Translator
description: A new novel about Thomas Mann’s longstanding American translator portrays a woman ahead of her time and, despite her shortcomings, important to leading Mann to a Nobel Prize.
content: Before she could sign on to translate the entirety of Thomas Mann, the giant of German letters, into English, Helen Tracy Lowe-Porter had to translate herself.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle
title: Northern Ireland’s D.U.P. Signals End to Political Deadlock After 2 Years
description: The Democratic Unionist Party said it had agreed a deal to return to power-sharing after negotiating with the British government.
content: The Democratic Unionist Party, the main Protestant party in Northern Ireland and one of its biggest political forces, said on Tuesday that it was ready to return to power sharing after a boycott of almost two years had paralyzed decision-making in the region.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John McWhorter
title: When We Do, and Don’t, Need a New Phrase to Describe Reality
description: We get by fine with one word for “blue.”
content: In my last newsletter, I argued that it is unsuitably awkward for the word “plagiarism” to be applied both to the stealing of others’ ideas and the copying, perhaps accidentally, of boilerplate text without citing its source. To the extent that most would consider the former an egregious transgression and the latter more of a lazy misstep, English would benefit from using a different term for it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: MAGA Is Based on Fear, Not Grounded in Reality
description: And the fear needn’t reflect reality.
content: A few days ago, Kristi Noem, the Republican governor of South Dakota — a MAGA hard-liner sometimes mentioned as a potential running mate for Donald Trump — warned that President Biden is “remaking” America, turning us into Europe. My first thought was: So he’s going to raise our life expectancy by five or six years? In context, however, it was clear that Noem believes, or expects her audience to believe, that Europe is a scene of havoc wrought by hordes of immigrants.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erica Berry
title: What Can Americans Agree on? Wolves.
description: In expanding pockets of the West, citizens across the political spectrum are finding common ground as they adjust to living beside wolves.
content: For generations, America waged a war against the wolf; now with the animals repopulating the Mountain West, the wolf war has taken on a new shape: pitting neighbors against neighbors as they fight over how to manage wolves.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Kenigsberg
title: Three Great Documentaries to Stream
description: Economic exploitation, climate change, entrenched corruption: These acclaimed films find fascination in catastrophe.
content: The proliferation of documentaries on streaming services makes it difficult to choose what to watch. Each month, we’ll choose three nonfiction films — classics, overlooked recent docs and more — that will reward your time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronen Bergman
title: Israeli Military Confirms It Has Begun Flooding Hamas Tunnels
description: It is the first time the military has publicly acknowledged using the tactic, which the U.N. has warned could damage Gaza’s drinking water.
content: The Israeli military said Tuesday that it had begun pumping water into the vast network of tunnels beneath Gaza, which Hamas has used to launch attacks, store weapons and imprison Israeli hostages.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sergey Ponomarev
title: Hope Wanes Amid the Wreckage Where 600 Apartments Once Stood
description: No building remains intact at 600 Konut, an apartment complex in Antakya, Turkey, near the epicenter of the earthquake. Many residents were killed in the collapse.
content: This was featured on the home screen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher F. Schuetze
title: German Authorities Seize $2 Billion Worth of Bitcoin
description: The police described the transfer of funds as the “most extensive seizure of Bitcoins by law enforcement in the Federal Republic of Germany.”
content: A German programmer who is accused of running an illegal movie streaming site more than a decade ago transferred $2.17 billion worth of Bitcoin to the authorities to repay at least some of the money he had made illegally, the police said on Tuesday. The transfer required the man to use his unique Bitcoin credentials to hand over the funds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Madison Malone Kircher
title: A Tote Bag for $120?
description: Emily Mariko, best known for her viral salmon bowl, draws criticism for peddling a pricey canvas bag.
content: Picture a tote bag. A really big tote bag, cut extra wide to fit your entire farmer’s market haul, with wide straps to evenly distribute weight while you lug your satsuma mandarins and eggs and the kale you’ll forget about and leave to rot in the bottom drawer of your refrigerator. It’s 100 percent cotton, made in the United States and comes in a ballet pink or a lovely faded olive color.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle
title: ‘A Long Time Coming’: Northern Ireland Deal Receives Broad Welcome
description: An agreement by the Democratic Unionist Party to return to power-sharing with Sinn Fein after a two year boycott was greeted by widespread relief.
content: Britain, Ireland and the United States on Tuesday welcomed a deal to end almost two years of political deadlock in Northern Ireland that will, for the first time, hand the territory’s top leadership role to Sinn Fein, a party that mainly represents Roman Catholic voters committed to a united Ireland.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: Do Housing Developers Need a (Tax) Break?
description: The 421a program expired in 2022. Developers and many officials say it was crucial in getting rental apartments built, but replacing it is politically challenging.
content: Good morning. It’s Tuesday. Today we’ll find out about a tax break that expired in 2022 — and why the fight over replacing it has implications for New York City’s future. We’ll also get details on why the City Council is expected to override Mayor Eric Adams’s veto of two bills today.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Yee, Abu Bakr Bashir and Gaya Gupta
title: The War the World Can’t See
description: From outside Gaza, the scale of death and destruction is impossible to grasp, shrouded by communications blackouts, restrictions barring international reporters and extreme challenges facing local journalists.
content: To many people outside Gaza, the war flashes by as a doomscroll of headlines and casualty tolls and photos of screaming children, the bloody shreds of somebody else’s anguish.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sergey Ponomarev
title: Apocalyptic Scenes as Workers Sift Through Rubble in Turkey
description: When I arrived in southern Turkey on Tuesday, residents had joined the search for bodies as rescue workers continued to sift through endless mountains of debris.
content: This was featured on the home screen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: Syphilis Is Soaring in the U.S.
description: Cases have risen by 80 percent since 2018, the C.D.C. reported. But chlamydia remains far more common.
content: Syphilis, once nearly eliminated in the United States, continues to resurge, reaching the highest rate of new infections recorded since 1950, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frank Rojas
title: Megan Thee Stallion and Nicki Minaj: Who’s Mad at Whom?
description: The two rappers ratcheted up hostilities with a pair of blustery, acid-dipped singles, each aiming to hit the other where it hurts.
content: In terms of social media oxygen consumed, not even Taylor Swift’s making it into the Super Bowl could compete with the weekend’s real main event: the very public drawing of battle lines between two titans of contemporary hip-hop.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ed Shanahan
title: Brooklyn Jewish Newspaper’s Ex-Top Editor Pleads Guilty to Jan. 6 Charge
description: Elliot Resnick, a longtime journalist at The Jewish Press, admitted that he impeded officers’ efforts to keep a mob from storming the U.S. Capitol.
content: A onetime top editor of an Orthodox Jewish newspaper in Brooklyn pleaded guilty on Tuesday to obstructing police officers’ efforts to hold off the mob that stormed the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Reed
title: Saudi Aramco Abruptly Drops Plans to Expand Oil Production
description: The pullback, at the behest of the Saudi government and made with little comment, probably reflects a more subdued outlook for demand of Saudi Arabia’s oil.
content: Saudi Aramco said Tuesday that it would call off plans to expand its oil output, a remarkable turnaround by one of the world’s leading petroleum producers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Wang and Tiffany May
title: Hong Kong Pushes New Security Law to Root Out ‘Seeds of Unrest’
description: Warning of threats posed by spies, the city’s leader expressed confidence that the new law would enjoy public support. “They will love it,” he said.
content: The Hong Kong government will enact a long-shelved security law to curb foreign influence and expand the definition of offenses like stealing state secrets and treason, officials announced on Tuesday, in a move expected to further silence dissent in the once-freewheeling Chinese territory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aaron Boxerman, Ronen Bergman, Adam Rasgon and Thomas Fuller
title: Israel Raids West Bank Hospital as Clashes Erupt With Hamas in Northern Gaza
description: The raid, by a small team wearing medical garb, came as Israel confirmed it was trying to flush militants out of tunnels with seawater and had renewed fighting in northern Gaza.
content: One of the Israeli soldiers wore medical scrubs, another a white coat and surgical mask. Their team swept into the West Bank hospital brandishing rifles, took up positions by the waiting-room chairs, then entered a patient’s room and killed a Hamas commander.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gia Kourlas
title: The Ballet Roots of a Broadway Star
description: Chita Rivera saw herself as a dancer, and that’s fitting: Her early ballet training was her secret weapon — and it never left her body.
content: Chita Rivera grew up to be a Broadway queen, but you can’t leave out that she was a ballet kid. Her training began after a botched jump at her family home in Washington, D.C. Rivera — still Dolores Conchita Figueroa del Rivero at the time — landed on the coffee table. It shattered.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neal E. Boudette
title: G.M. Profits Hurt by Electric Car Business and Strike
description: The automaker has placed a bet on electric vehicles, but it has struggled to produce and sell the vehicles in large numbers.
content: General Motors said on Tuesday that its profit in the final three months of 2023 was depressed by the cost of a 40-day strike at some of its U.S. plants and an accounting charge related to electric vehicles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aimee Ortiz
title: Pieces of Jackie Robinson Statue Are Found Burning in Kansas Park
description: The life-size bronze tribute to the legendary baseball player who broke the color barrier was stolen from a different park last week. What was left of it “is beyond repair,” officials said.
content: Parts of a life-size bronze statue that celebrated the legacy of the legendary baseball player and civil rights figure Jackie Robinson were found dismantled and burned early Tuesday after it had been stolen from a Kansas park last week, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Connie Chang and Nicholas Sansone
title: Lizards, Monkeys and Bears, Oh My! Try the Animal Movement Workout.
description: Crawling around like a crab or gorilla has become a bona fide exercise fad. It looks a little silly, but it’s also a serious workout.
content: Lately, my workouts have looked a bit odd: I’ve been slithering like a lizard, crawling like a bear and scuttling like a crab. It’s called quadrupedal movement training (or animal movement), and it’s taken over TikTok (the related hashtag, #primalmovement, has 2.4 billion views).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Graham Bowley
title: Jury Finds Sotheby’s Did Not Help in Any Fraud of Russian Oligarch
description: Dmitry Rybolovlev had accused the auction house of aiding a Swiss art dealer who he says cheated him out of tens of millions of dollars.
content: A jury in a civil trial in New York decided in favor of Sotheby’s on Tuesday, rejecting a Russian oligarch’s claim that the auction house had helped a Swiss dealer who he said defrauded him out of tens of millions of dollars in high-end art sales.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Red Sorghum Brings Vintage Chinese Glamour to Long Island City
description: Third Kingdom focuses on mushrooms in the East Village, Quique Crudo brings Cosme Aguilar’s small plates to the West Village and more restaurant news.
content: The 1930s romanticized movie-set look of China, with fringed hanging lanterns, vermilion accents, wicker and greenery, has come to Long Island City. The elaborate new restaurant from Vincent Lin and his business partner, Mandy Zhang, who also own Blue Willow in Midtown Manhattan and Ye’s Apothecary in Chinatown, and their executive chef, Bruce Li, showcase Sichuan and Hunan cooking here. The menu is peppered with Sichuan wontons, Xiang Xi fried rice, Chairman’s braised pork, Chongqing braised beef, peppercorn fish stew and a number of Mala dry pot dishes starring ingredients like pork belly, tripe, Spam, potatoes and mushrooms. Traditional Chinese American standbys like kung pao chicken and lo mein are also served. The drinks list is heavy on the baiju, a spirit made from sorghum and often raised in glasses for celebrations; the list of cocktails mixed with the spirit is extensive, devised by Robert Burns, the mixologist for the partners’ three restaurants. The owners selected a Long Island City location for the diversity of the neighborhood.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Callie Holtermann
title: 394 Hot Dog Ice Sculptures Later, He Quit His Day Job
description: The artist who goes by Sunday Nobody has found millions of viewers with his elaborate, absurdist projects. They are not, he insists, “a waste of a human life.”
content: One day this summer, a man in Seattle gathered ingredients to make hot dogs: sausages, buns, a 50-pound block of aluminum.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes
title: War in Ukraine Has Weakened Putin, C.I.A. Director Writes
description: William J. Burns says Russia’s invasion of Ukraine has created recruiting opportunities for the spy agency and ushered in a new era.
content: The war in Ukraine has “quietly corroded” the power of President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, the C.I.A. director, William J. Burns, wrote in an essay published on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael S. Schmidt, David A. Fahrenthold and Billy Witz
title: N.C.A.A. Inquiry Takes On Growing Role of Booster Groups
description: The University of Tennessee’s football program is under investigation for recruiting violations involving a donor collective, signaling an effort to rein in the role of outside money in college sports.
content: The N.C.A.A. is investigating the University of Tennessee’s football program for recruiting violations involving a group of outside donors, signaling an escalation of efforts to rein in the growing influence of money flooding into college sports, according to documents and people familiar with the case.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Cappelle
title: ‘Passport’ Review: A Master of Comedy in a Migrant Camp
description: The new show by Alexis Michalik, a star of commercial theater, wades into political battles in France, where immigration restrictions have been at the forefront of the government’s agenda.
content: Badly injured from a fight, a man wakes up in the Calais Jungle, a ramshackle camp for migrants in northern France. His memory is gone, and all he has on him is an Eritrean passport with the name “Issa.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Yoon
title: North Atlantic Right Whale Found Dead Near Martha’s Vineyard
description: The whale washed ashore with a rope wrapped around it. About 360 of the critically endangered species remain.
content: A female North Atlantic right whale was found dead on Sunday with a rope wrapped around it off the coast of Martha’s Vineyard, Mass., a rare event that had scientists worrying about the future of the critically endangered species with about 360 remaining animals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erica Sweeney
title: Is Lip Balm Making My Chapped Lips Worse?
description: It can be a helpful barrier between your lips and the cold wind, but not all products are created equal.
content: Q: My lips are always dry, and I’m applying lip balm on repeat. Could this be exacerbating the problem?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lucy Corin
title: What Your Laundry Says About Your Life
description: What you’ve gone through and how you wear it, one wash cycle at a time.
content: My father has placed me in the basket and layered laundry neatly on top of me, then topped everything with a crocheted blanket. Time stamp: epitome of the ’70s. I’m ... 5? He has employed a classic parental trick, his version called Rock, inspired by Frank Zappa’s “Help, I’m a Rock,” which I also recommend. The game was: Pretend you’re a rock. You’re quiet. You’re still. I remember the weight of the laundry, the solemnity of my task and the laughter just beneath it. Something about the princess and the pea: being the pea.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane, Jessica Jaglois and Eduardo Medina
title: Memphis Releases New Footage From Night of Tyre Nichols’s Fatal Beating
description: The additional 21 hours of recordings offer a fuller picture of what happened after the traffic stop, but they do not show what led to it.
content: The city of Memphis released on Tuesday hours of audio, surveillance and police body-camera footage that offered a fuller picture of the night police officers fatally beat Tyre Nichols, a 29-year-old Black FedEx worker, during a traffic stop last January.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard C. Paddock and Muktita Suhartono
title: Arms Dealer Linked to Myanmar Junta Acquitted in Thai Money Laundering Case
description: U Tun Min Latt was placed under sanctions last year by the United States for supplying drones and aircraft parts to the military regime in Myanmar.
content: A wealthy Myanmar arms broker with close ties to the leader of Myanmar’s brutal military regime was acquitted on Tuesday by a Bangkok court on charges of drug trafficking and money laundering, raising fears that he will be free to resume his activities aiding the junta.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear, Hamed Aleaziz and Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: How the Border Crisis Shattered Biden’s Immigration Hopes
description: An examination of President Biden’s record reveals how he failed to overcome a surge in new arrivals and political obstacles in both parties.
content: On President Biden’s first day in office, he paused nearly all deportations. He vowed to end the harsh practices of the Trump administration, show compassion toward those wishing to come to the United States and secure the southern border.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer and Marc Santora
title: Ukraine’s Latest Challenge: Festering Tension Among Top Leaders
description: Rampant speculation that President Volodymyr Zelensky will fire his top military commander has consumed Ukraine’s capital at a precarious moment in the war.
content: As Ukraine fights against a fierce Russian offensive and its leaders wait to see whether their Western allies will approve more than $100 billion in much-needed assistance, the government in Kyiv is dealing with a festering distraction: tumult in its top ranks centered on the fate of the top military commander.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: Global Economy Is Heading Toward ‘Soft Landing,’ I.M.F. Says
description: The International Monetary Fund upgraded its growth forecasts and offered a more optimistic outlook for the world economy.
content: The global economy has been battered by a pandemic, record levels of inflation, protracted wars and skyrocketing interest rates over the past four years, raising fears of a painful worldwide downturn. But fresh forecasts published on Tuesday suggest that the world has managed to defy the odds, averting the threat of a so-called hard landing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aurelien Breeden
title: French Lawmakers Vote to Enshrine Abortion Rights in Constitution
description: Most of France’s political parties broadly support the right to abortion. But the proposal still has to undergo a long and complex legislative process before it comes to fruition.
content: French lawmakers on Tuesday overwhelmingly approved a bill to enshrine abortion rights in France’s Constitution, the first step in a complex legislative process that began in direct response to the U.S. Supreme Court’s decision to overturn Roe v. Wade.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: What’s the Matter With Europe?
description: Long term, not much. But policy is too tight now.
content: In my most recent column I had a bit of fun with Kristi Noem, the governor of South Dakota, who has ominously warned that President Biden will turn us into Europe. I joked that this would mean adding five or six years to our life expectancy. When I shared Noem’s remarks on social media, some of my correspondents asked whether this meant that we’re about to get good train service and better food.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jin Yu Young
title: If It Isn’t Perfect, Is It Still K-Pop?
description: Musical acts like Balming Tiger are challenging the idea that K-pop is nothing but polished, perfectly synchronized boy bands and girl groups.
content: What comes to mind when you hear the word “K-pop”? Is it the global boy band phenomenon BTS, wearing studded jackets and dancing in perfect sync? Or the girl group Blackpink, performing at Coachella in trendy fashions and perfectly curled hair?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: oneiric
description: This word has appeared in six articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word oneiric has appeared in six articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Oct. 2 in the book review “Daniel Clowes Dreams of the Apocalypse” by Junot Díaz:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edward Wong and Julian E. Barnes
title: Officials Propose to Hamas a Six-Week War Pause and a Hostage-Prisoner Swap
description: The United States, Israel, Egypt and Qatar sketched out a bare-bones framework in Paris. Qatari officials are awaiting word from Hamas.
content: Representatives from four nations have agreed to have Qatar present a nascent framework to Hamas that proposes a six-week pause in the war in Gaza for Hamas to exchange some hostages for Palestinian prisoners held by Israel, officials say.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández and Jin Yu Young
title: Jaap van Zweden, New York Phil Maestro, Takes Podium in Seoul
description: The conductor officially began his tenure as the Seoul Philharmonic Orchestra’s new music director, months before he is to step down in New York.
content: In New York, Jaap van Zweden, the New York Philharmonic’s music director, is preparing to say goodbye: Farewell concerts under the banner “Celebrate Jaap!” are planned over the next few months before his brief, pandemic-interrupted tenure ends this summer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Corkery
title: Oregon Leaders Declare Drug Emergency in Portland
description: Oregon’s governor, Tina Kotek, hopes to counter homelessness, crime and widespread public use of fentanyl that she says threatens the state’s largest city.
content: Oregon leaders on Tuesday declared a 90-day state of emergency in central Portland as part of a broad effort to tackle the effects of fentanyl on the streets of the state’s largest city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shannon Sims
title: Is It Safe to Travel to the Bahamas? Here’s What You Need to Know.
description: A string of gang-related murders in the local community prompted the U.S. embassy in the island nation to issue a security alert.
content: Drawn by clear turquoise waters and miles of white-sand beaches, around seven million travelers visit the Bahamas each year, but a new warning about increased violence on the island nation has raised alarm over the safety of visiting there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yiwen Lu
title: Watch Me Lose My Job on TikTok
description: Some tech workers are filming their layoffs and sharing them on social media. They say it’s part catharsis, part transparency.
content: “I am about to get laid off,” Folashade Ade-Banjo spoke to the camera while positioning her phone, “and you are about to see it.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. Edward Moreno
title: UPS to Cut 12,000 Jobs as Wages Rise and Package Volumes Fall
description: After what the company called a “difficult and disappointing” 2023, UPS said the cuts would save $1 billion this year.
content: United Parcel Service plans to cut about 12,000 jobs this year as the company tries to slash costs in the face of falling package volumes and higher wages linked to a union contract it signed in the summer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Proulx
title: Is True Crime As a Form of Entertainment Ethical?
description: A writer and activist says the genre can be harmful to victims and their families. What do you think?
content: True crime entertainment seems to be everywhere these days. Are you a fan? Do you listen to podcasts, read books, or watch documentaries, TV shows and movies that tell the stories of real-life victims and perpetrators?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ron Lieber
title: Colleges Won’t Get FAFSA Data Until March, Delaying Aid Offers
description: The wait will make it difficult for many schools to finalize financial aid packages, despite already offering admissions to high school seniors.
content: It may be another few months before millions of students and families know how much they’ll have to pay for college this fall.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Debra Kamin
title: New York Asks Realty Company to Investigate Sexual Assault Allegations
description: The state comptroller wants eXp Realty to look into allegations that female real estate agents were drugged and assaulted during company events.
content: The New York state comptroller has asked the real estate brokerage eXp Realty to open an independent investigation into sexual harassment and assault allegations exposed in a New York Times article last month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: Canada Delays Plan to Offer Medically Assisted Death to the Mentally Ill
description: A parliamentary panel concluded that there are not enough doctors, particularly psychiatrists, in the country to properly assess patients.
content: Canada is postponing a plan to offer people suffering from mental illnesses the option of a medically assisted death, two cabinet ministers said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily LaBarge
title: Josephine Baker, Still Moving
description: She entertained Europe between the wars and still inspires artists and activists now, as a new exhibition in Berlin shows.
content: There was no shortage of epithets for Josephine Baker, the St. Louis-born polymath who took Paris by storm when she arrived there in 1925, aged 19, to headline “La Revue Nègre,” a show of all-Black performers at the Théâtre des Champs-Élysées.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zeynep Tufekci and Vishakha Darbha
title: I’m Not a Fan of TikTok, but We Can’t Blame It for Everything
description: Instead of scapegoating social media, start regulating it.
content: Gen Z and younger millennials are taking to apps like TikTok to express their anger about everything from the conflict in the Middle East to the cost of living. Some politicians are not happy. In this audio essay, the Opinion columnist Zeynep Tufekci argues that lawmakers should stop blaming social media platforms for corrupting people’s minds and instead concentrate on oversight and demand transparency from them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aurelien Breeden
title: French Government Vows Rapid Aid for Farmers but Blockades Persist
description: Protesters blocking roads in and out of Paris, who say farms are squeezed by low prices and excessive regulation, seemed unmoved by promises from Prime Minister Gabriel Attal.
content: Prime Minister Gabriel Attal promised more aid for French agriculture on Tuesday and vowed to shield it from “unfair competition” in an attempt to appease protesting farmers, but many appeared unmoved by his efforts as they blocked major roads around Paris for a second day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Stephen Colbert Is Hoping for a Taylor Swift Super Bowl
description: With the Kansas City Chiefs in the game, Colbert can’t wait to see “the biggest star in the N.F.L.” (if she can get there from Japan in time).
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Walker
title: Norfolk Southern Agrees to Try Out Federal Safety Reporting Program
description: The company, which operated the train that derailed in East Palestine, Ohio, is the first major freight railroad to join a federal program that allows workers to report safety issues.
content: Norfolk Southern, the operator of the freight train carrying toxic chemicals that derailed in East Palestine, Ohio, nearly a year ago, has agreed to participate in a federal program that allows employees to report safety issues confidentially, the company and federal officials announced on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lola Fadulu
title: Ohio Man Who Threw Molotov Cocktails at a Church Gets 18 Years in Prison
description: Aimenn D. Penny, 20, was angry because the Community Church of Chesterland had planned to host two drag shows, federal prosecutors said.
content: An Ohio man who prosecutors said had tried to burn down a church in anger by throwing Molotov cocktails at it last year because it planned to host two drag shows was sentenced on Monday to 18 years in prison, federal authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Technology Companies Are Cutting Jobs and Wall Street Likes It
description: The sector is laying off workers after a hiring boom during the pandemic and their share prices are soaring.
content: Tech giants are set to report quarterly earnings, starting on Tuesday with Alphabet and Microsoft. Wall Street is expecting good news, including more progress on artificial intelligence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: An Explorer Believes He Found Amelia Earhart’s Plane. Experts Aren’t Convinced.
description: A robotics company captured a sonar image that its chief executive believes shows Earhart’s long-lost plane at the bottom of the Pacific Ocean. Archaeologists say it’s too early to know.
content: It is one of the greatest enduring mysteries in aviation history: the disappearance of Amelia Earhart after she took off from Lae, New Guinea, in a Lockheed 10-E Electra on July 2, 1937.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: The Women of ‘Feud: Capote vs. the Swans’ Are Birds of a Feather
description: Famous women play the famous women in Ryan Murphy’s new period drama. In a group interview, they discuss the series and the burdens of public life.
content: The first season of Ryan Murphy’s “Feud” aired in 2017. A juicy survey of the bitter rivalry between Bette Davis and Joan Crawford, the co-stars of “What Ever Happened to Baby Jane?,” the show earned 18 Emmy nominations, winning two. A second season, based on Prince Charles and Princess Diana’s troubled marriage, was developed then scrapped, mostly because Murphy felt that he could never outdo “The Crown.” Another iteration, centered on William F. Buckley and Gore Vidal, also fell apart. Murphy and his producers toyed with a half dozen other ideas, though never for very long.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Fausset and Danny Hakim
title: Prosecutor on Trump Georgia Case Avoids Testifying in Divorce Proceeding
description: The prosecutor, Nathan Wade, might have been forced to address allegations of a romantic relationship with his boss, Fani T. Willis, at a divorce hearing this week.
content: The special prosecutor leading the election interference case against former President Donald J. Trump will not have to testify this week about an alleged romantic relationship with his boss, Fani T. Willis, the Fulton County district attorney, after reaching a temporary agreement in his divorce case on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: A Lead Scare Strikes Stanley Tumblers, but You Don’t Need to Worry
description: There is some lead in the sealing material used in the cup, the company says. But experts say it’s inaccessible to people drinking from one, and caution that at-home lead tests are unreliable.
content: You might have heard of the Stanley tumbler, the hip, trendy water bottle that has people camping outside stores or getting into fights to get their hands on one.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: Taylor Swift, Travis Kelce and a MAGA Meltdown
description: The fulminations surrounding the world’s biggest pop icon — and girlfriend of Chiefs tight end Travis Kelce — reached the stratosphere after Kansas City made it to the Super Bowl.
content: For football fans eager to see a new team in the Super Bowl, the conference championship games on Sunday that sent the Kansas City Chiefs and San Francisco 49ers back to the main event of American sports culture were sorely disappointing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Flavelle
title: U.S. Will Pay to Add Solar Panels to Hospitals, Schools After Disasters
description: The federal government plans to reimburse state and local governments that rebuild damaged public buildings to be more energy resilient.
content: The Federal Emergency Management Agency will begin paying to install solar panels on schools, hospitals and other public buildings that are rebuilt after disasters, making them more resilient against future disasters while reducing greenhouse gas emissions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Astead W. Herndon, Caitlin O'Keefe, Mary Wilson, Asthaa Chaturvedi, Clare Toeniskoetter, Rachel Dry, Rachel Quester, Paige Cowett, John Ketchum, Dan Powell and Alyssa Moxley
title: Trump’s Voters vs. Haley’s Donors
description: A class war is playing out inside the Republican Party.
content: Inside the Republican Party, a class war is playing out between the pro-Trump base, which is ready for the nomination fight to be over, and the anti-Trump donor class, which thinks it’s just getting started.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aaron Boxerman
title: Israeli Forces Kill a Hamas Commander Inside a West Bank Hospital, Military Says
description: Surveillance video released by the Palestinian Authority shows several gunmen in apparent civilian clothing brandishing weapons in the hospital.
content: Israeli forces stormed a Palestinian hospital in the occupied West Bank early Tuesday morning, killing three militants, including a commander in Hamas, according to the Israeli military and Palestinian officials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: Love Letters to California
description: Readers share what they love about their part of the state.
content: On a recent short drive from my home in San Francisco, I ended up in Petaluma, where I had as close to a perfect day as possible.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: If It Walks Like an Insurrection and Talks Like an Insurrection …
description: Trump has no rightful place in the leadership of the American Republic.
content: While we await oral argument in Trump v. Anderson — the U.S. Supreme Court case that will evaluate the Colorado Supreme Court’s decision to exclude the former president from the state’s Republican primary ballot — it’s worth revisiting the arguments leveled against the Colorado court’s decision and, by extension, its interpretation of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment to the U.S. Constitution.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Moses
title: Minute-Long Soap Operas Are Here. Is America Ready?
description: Popularized in China during the pandemic, ReelShort and other apps are hoping to bring minute-by-minute melodramas to the United States.
content: When Albee Zhang received an offer to produce cheesy short-form features made for phones last spring, she was skeptical, and so, she declined.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman and Shane Goldmacher
title: Trump’s PACs Spent Roughly $50 Million on Legal Expenses in 2023
description: The former president is facing four criminal indictments and potential trials that could drive his legal bills even higher as he seeks to lock up the Republican presidential nomination.
content: Donald J. Trump piled up legal expenses in 2023 as he was indicted four times, spending approximately $50 million in donor money on legal bills and investigation-related expenses last year, according to two people briefed on the figure.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Louise Snyder
title: An America Where Guns Do the Talking
description: Two new books consider how the country’s obsession with firearms has become an existential threat.
content: Last year, a friend from Brunei visited me in the United States. She is American but was raised in Sudan and has lived in Cambodia and Scotland, among other places. We were talking about the rise in anxiety among teenagers in America when another friend texted me; her daughter had just arrived home from school, where she’d spent the afternoon in lockdown. “Of course your kids have anxiety,” my Brunei friend said. “They’re being raised in a war zone.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Anthes
title: First Bird Flu Deaths Reported in Antarctic Penguins
description: Dead gentoo penguins tested positive for the virus, and at least one suspected case has been reported in king penguins.
content: A highly lethal form of bird flu has been detected in Antarctic penguins for the first time. The virus, which is known as H5N1, was confirmed in two gentoo penguins that were found dead on Sea Lion Island in the Falkland Islands, a British territory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracey Tully
title: Tax Break Scandal Leads to $5 Million Fine for N.J. Energy Company
description: The penalty allows Holtec International to avoid criminal charges after an investigation into tax breaks linked closely to George Norcross III, a powerful Democrat.
content: A business tied to George Norcross III, a high-profile New Jersey Democrat, has agreed to pay a $5 million penalty after a criminal investigation into hundreds of millions of dollars in tax breaks that the energy company, Holtec International, was awarded.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alissa J. Rubin
title: What Iran Really Wants
description: The nation is at the center of the current turmoil in the Middle East.
content: Iran has emerged as the chief architect in multiple conflicts strafing the Middle East, from the Mediterranean to the Persian Gulf.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Jimy Williams, A.L. Manager of the Year in Boston in ’99, Dies at 80
description: He led the Red Sox into the playoffs twice, had managing stints in Toronto and Houston, and won more than 900 games as a dugout skipper.
content: Jimy Williams, the 1999 American League Manager of the Year for Boston who won 910 games over a dozen seasons that included stints with Toronto and Houston, died on Friday in Tarpon Springs, Fla. He was 80.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Eligon
title: Zuma’s Enduring Appeal Threatens His Old Allies’ Hold on South Africa
description: Six years after he was forced from office, former President Jacob Zuma, who still has a loyal following, is campaigning for opponents of the party he once led, the African National Congress.
content: When the African National Congress suspended former President Jacob Zuma this week, a top party official portrayed him as a traitor to the ongoing struggle for Black prosperity in South Africa and a symbol of corruption that the organization is looking to move past.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Petr Lom and Corinne van Egeraat
title: Our Friend Is Gone, but He Lives Through Our Resistance in Myanmar
description: After the 2021 military coup in Myanmar, loved ones of the deceased artist and political prisoner San Zaw Htway wrote him letters as an act of remembrance and hope.
content: San Zaw Htway was an artist, activist, political prisoner and dear friend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Judson Jones
title: Here’s How the Next Two Atmospheric Rivers Will Affect California
description: A storm hitting California late Tuesday into Thursday will set the stage for another week of unsettled weather across the state.
content: Forecasters have warned California residents that unsettled weather between Tuesday and Thursday is likely to bring flooding rains, strong winds and mountain snow as another atmospheric river moves down along the West Coast. Another storm will threaten the region early next week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mitch Smith
title: Trump Stays on Ballot in Illinois, State Board Rules
description: The state elections board said that it did not have the authority to decide whether Donald Trump had engaged in insurrection.
content: The Illinois State Board of Elections rejected a complaint on Tuesday that accused former President Donald J. Trump of insurrection by trying to remain in office after losing the 2020 election, and that sought to disqualify him from the state’s primary ballot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lakshya Jain and Armin Thomas
title: Trump Has Devoured the Republican Establishment
description: No matter which way you slice it, he is the engine of the party.
content: It was almost 15 months ago that The New York Post published a full-page cover photo of Ron DeSantis with the headline “DeFUTURE.” His 19-point victory in the Florida governor’s race was one of the few bright spots of the 2022 elections for a weary Republican elite, which was desperately looking to move on from Donald Trump after his handpicked candidates cost the party key Senate seats.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Gelles and Kenneth P. Vogel
title: Patagonia’s Profits Are Funding Conservation — and Politics
description: $71 million of the clothing company’s earnings have been used since September 2022 to fund wildlife restoration, dam removal and Democratic groups.
content: A little more than $3 million to block a proposed mine in Alaska. Another $3 million to conserve land in Chile and Argentina. And $1 million to help elect Democrats around the country, including $200,000 to a super PAC this month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nico Grant
title: Alphabet’s Search Revenue Disappoints in Fourth Quarter
description: Google’s parent company reported that sales climbed 13 percent to $86.3 billion while profit jumped 52 percent.
content: Alphabet, Google’s parent company, on Tuesday reported search revenue and a profit margin for its latest quarter that fell short of Wall Street’s expectations, in a sign that growth in its flagship business and recent layoffs, intended to cut costs, were not enough to offset its growing investment in artificial intelligence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nossiter
title: Khaled Nezzar, General at Center of Algeria’s Bloodshed, Dies at 86
description: In the 1990s, he oversaw troops that committed a host of atrocities against equally brutal Islamist rebels in what became known as the Black Decade.
content: Khaled Nezzar, a wily, outspoken Algerian general and former defense minister who played a central role in the bloodshed that marked his troubled country’s passage out of the 20th century, died on Dec. 29 in Algiers. He was 86.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lindsay Zoladz
title: Was 1968 the Grammys’ Best Year Ever?
description: Before the 2024 awards on Sunday, revisit a ceremony where the Recording Academy got it right, honoring the Beatles, Bobbie Gentry, Aretha Franklin and more.
content: The 66th annual Grammy Awards take place on Sunday, and this year’s lineup of performers is pretty exceptional. I mean, Joni Mitchell is performing! For the first time ever at the Grammys! I could really just stop there, but Billy Joel, Billie Eilish, SZA, U2, Olivia Rodrigo, Burna Boy, Luke Combs, Dua Lipa, Travis Scott and more are scheduled to grace the stage. Will Joel and Eilish take this opportunity to start a supergroup called the Billies? Will SZA and U2 start an all-caps collaborative side project called SUZA2? Will Travis Scott meet Joni Mitchell, and if so, what will they talk about? The possibilities of this year’s ceremony are endless, and a little weird.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Attacking, and Defending, D.E.I. in America
description: Responses to a front-page article and a guest essay about diversity, equity and inclusion. Also: The death penalty; saving rivers; Donald Trump and celebrity.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmanuel Morgan
title: Joel Embiid Wants the African Diaspora to Flourish Onscreen
description: “I’ve always been passionate about storytelling,” said the N.B.A. star, whose production studio will create a documentary about Memphis Depay’s success on the Dutch soccer team.
content: Joel Embiid knew as early as his rookie season in the National Basketball Association that he eventually wanted to enter the media industry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert D. McFadden
title: Chita Rivera, Electrifying Star of Broadway and Beyond, Is Dead at 91
description: Appearing in scores of stage productions, she dazzled audiences for nearly six decades, most memorably starring as Anita in “West Side Story” and Velma Kelly in “Chicago.”
content: Chita Rivera, the fire-and-ice dancer, singer and actress who leapt to stardom in the original Broadway production of “West Side Story” and dazzled audiences for nearly seven decades as a Puerto Rican lodestar of the American musical theater, died on Tuesday in New York. She was 91.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ryan Mac
title: Neuralink Implanted a Device in a Patient’s Brain, Elon Musk Says
description: The billionaire said his company’s first product, called Telepathy, would let a person control a phone or computer “just by thinking.”
content: Neuralink, a company working to develop computer interfaces that can be implanted in human brains, placed its first device in a patient on Sunday, said its founder, Elon Musk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Cain Miller, Alicia Parlapiano and Margot Sanger-Katz
title: More Money for Parents? Both Parties Just Might Make It Happen.
description: If an expansion of the child tax credit passed, here’s what would change and who would benefit.
content: At a time when congressional Democrats and Republicans seem unable to agree on almost anything, they may soon pass an expanded child tax credit, which gives money to parents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Why Cut Rates in an Economy This Strong? A Big Question Confronts the Fed.
description: The central bank is widely expected to lower interest rates this year. But with growth and consumer spending chugging along, explaining it may take some work.
content: The Federal Reserve is widely expected to leave interest rates unchanged at the conclusion of its meeting on Wednesday, but investors will be watching closely for any hint at when and how much it might lower those rates this year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiffany May and Yan Zhuang
title: Amazon Filmed ‘Expats’ in Hong Kong, but People There Can’t Watch It
description: The first two episodes of the show, which was filmed during the city’s pandemic restrictions, were released last week but were not available there.
content: At the height of Hong Kong’s Covid restrictions, the government gave Nicole Kidman and several others a rare exemption from the weeks of hotel quarantine required for travelers so that they could film a series about the malaise of privileged expatriates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katrina Miller and Rosa Chávez Yacila
title: In Peru, a Mission to Save the Stingless Bee
description: Native to the tropics, these pollinators are taking a lead role in one of the latest efforts to conserve the Amazon rainforest.
content: As a child, Heriberto Vela, an Indigenous resident of Loreto, Peru, watched his father pull nests of wild stingless bees from trees in the Amazon forest. Together, the two then extracted honey from the nests to help cure colds and other ailments.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: A Monkey Is on the Run in the Scottish Highlands
description: “You would think we were chasing an international fugitive,” one resident said.
content: Was it a longing for freedom, for friends or for snacks that pushed the monkey to make his daring getaway?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Madison Malone Kircher and Bridget Bennett
title: She Gave Birth Two Weeks Ago. Now She’s in a Beauty Pageant.
description: Hannah Neeleman, a Utah homemaker with a huge social media following, goes to Las Vegas, newborn in tow, to compete for Mrs. World.
content: “I am still bleeding a little,” Hannah Neeleman said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: U.S. Weighs Retaliation After Strike in Jordan, and Farmers Lay ‘Siege’ to Paris
description: Plus, the Biden campaign wants Taylor Swift.
content: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: Haley Says U.S. Should ‘Go After’ Iranian Military Over Deadly Drone Strike
description: “This is surgical,” she said after a drone strike by an Iranian-backed militia killed three American service members. “You take one or two of them out.”
content: Nikki Haley suggested on Tuesday morning that the United States should “go after” Iranian military leaders in response to the drone attack by an Iran-backed militia that killed three American service members.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Callie Holtermann
title: Elmo Asked an Innocuous Question
description: Elmo was not expecting it to open a yawning chasm of despair.
content: On Monday the X account for Elmo, the fuzzy red monster from “Sesame Street,” posed a softball question to its 457,000 followers: “Elmo is just checking in! How is everybody doing?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Horowitz
title: Tiny Political Party Shuns Amnesty Measure, in Setback for Spanish Leader
description: A hard-line Catalan separatist party argued that the legislative shield against prosecution for alleged crimes linked to a failed bid for independence is weak and has to be broader.
content: The fragile coalition of Prime Minister Pedro Sánchez of Spain revealed deep and potentially paralyzing cracks on Tuesday when a tiny, hard-line Catalan separatist party he has allied with rejected a critical amnesty measure as unsatisfactory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green
title: Letha Dawson Scanzoni, Pioneer of Evangelical Feminism, Dies at 88
description: In books like “All We’re Meant to Be” and “Is the Homosexual My Neighbor?” she used the Bible to challenge beliefs that women were inferior to men and that homosexuality was a sin.
content: Letha Dawson Scanzoni, an evangelical author who argued, gently but persuasively, that the Bible considered women equal to men, inspiring a wave of Christian feminism and, perhaps inevitably, a backlash against it, died on Jan. 9 in Charlotte, N.C. She was 88.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Ley
title: New Subway Fare Gates and Platform Barriers Fail to Impress New Yorkers
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority is testing ways to address passenger safety and fare evasion. It’s not clear the pilots will be effective.
content: Transit officials have struggled for years with two of the subway system’s most vexing problems: the dozens of people struck by trains every year and the millions of dollars lost to fare beaters. In the latest efforts to find solutions, they are testing new fare gates to stop turnstile jumpers and metal platform barriers to keep riders safe.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quote of the Day: More Than Ever, Teenagers See a Bleak Future
description: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, January 30, 2024.
content: “The data is pretty stark: Our kids are not all right.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Orlando Mayorquin
title: Arkansas Authorities Capture Second Escaped Inmate
description: Jatonia Bryant, 23, had been held at a jail in Pine Bluff, Ark., on a capital murder charge before he and another inmate fled last week, the authorities said. The other escapee was caught Thursday.
content: The authorities in Arkansas on Monday captured a capital murder suspect who had escaped from a local jail with another inmate, ending a weeklong manhunt.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eileen Sullivan
title: Law Enforcement Braces for Flood of Child Sex Abuse Images Generated by A.I.
description: Artificial intelligence technology has drastically simplified the creation of images of children being exploited or abused, whether real or fake.
content: Law enforcement officials are bracing for an explosion of material generated by artificial intelligence that realistically depicts children being sexually exploited, deepening the challenge of identifying victims and combating such abuse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Correal and Genevieve Glatsky
title: Colombia, a Usually Wet Nation, Reels Amid Widespread Wildfires
description: Firefighters, many of them volunteers, have been confronting dozens of blazes amid high temperatures this month. The conditions have been linked to climate change.
content: Helicopters hauling buckets of water fly toward the mountains where fires burn, a thick haze periodically covers the sky, and residents have been ordered to wear masks and limit driving because of the poor air quality.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Republicans Push to Impeach Biden’s Homeland Security Chief
description: Also, Chita Rivera, the electrifying Broadway star, died at 91. Here's the latest at the end of Tuesday.
content: The Republican-led House panel on homeland security is set to advance articles of impeachment today, seeking to oust Alejandro Mayorkas, the homeland security secretary, for his handling of immigration at the southern U.S. border.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Isaac
title: Focused Cuts and Fewer Layers: Tech Layoffs Enter a New Phase
description: Amazon, Google, Microsoft and other tech companies have been on a layoff spree this month, with the latest cuts differing from last year’s mass reductions.
content: Last year, Mark Zuckerberg declared 2023 to be a “year of efficiency.” His company, Meta, soon laid off a third of its employees. Amazon, Google and Microsoft also cut tens of thousands of workers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sydney Ember
title: Boeing Faces Tricky Balance Between Safety and Financial Performance
description: The company is under pressure to show regulators and customers that it takes safety seriously and to reassure investors about its financial outlook.
content: Less than four weeks after a hole blew open on a Boeing 737 Max 9 jet during a flight, company executives face a thorny question: Should they emphasize safety or financial performance?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Corina Knoll
title: 5 Men Arrested in Mojave Desert Killings That Remained a Mystery for Days
description: Six victims were found in a remote area of San Bernardino County about 90 miles northeast of Los Angeles. The authorities believe the shooting deaths stemmed from a dispute over illegal marijuana.
content: The authorities in Southern California announced on Monday that they had arrested five men in connection with the six people found fatally shot at a remote crossroads in the Mojave Desert last week, a grisly scene that investigators believe stemmed from a dispute over marijuana.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Study Tracking Women’s Music Credits Has a Surprise: Good News
description: The Annenberg Inclusion Initiative’s latest report finds that women’s involvement in the biggest hits of 2023 was greatly improved over previous years.
